questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common cause of secondary Sjogren's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of secondary Sjögren’s syndrome is rheumatoid arthritis. Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the lacrimal and salivary 
glands. It also affects other organ systems, such as lungs, kidneys, and nervous system. It is seen 
in association with: • Rheumatoid arthritis • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Scleroderma • Mixed connective tissue disease • Primary biliary cirrhosis • Vasculitis • Chronic active hepatitis C

questions.question:
Question 2: Which is the most common extraglandular manifestation seen in patients diagnosed with 
Sjogren's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The most common extraglandular manifestation seen in patients with Sjögren’s syndrome is 
arthritis or arthralgia. The extraglandular manifestations in Sjögren’s syndrome are: • Arthralgia or arthritis - most common manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to 
Jaccoud's arthropathy. Jaccoud's arthropathy is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy 
characterized by the ulnar deviation of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint 
subluxation. • Raynaud's phenomenon • Interstitial lung disease - most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) • Renal tubular acidosis - Type 1 (distal) RTA • Primary biliary cirrhosis • Lymphoma - MALToma The give X-ray shows Jaccoud's arthropathy: 490

questions.question:
Question 4: A software engineer presented with complaints of dryness and itching of eyes on staring at his 
laptop screen. On examination, parotid swelling was noted and the test shown below was 484 
Sold by @itachibot positive. The serology of this patient is likely to be positive for which of the following 
antibodies?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of dry eyes, parotid swelling, and a positive Schirmer test is suggestive of 
Sjögren's syndrome. It is associated with anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B autoantibodies. The presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B indicate extra glandular involvement and poor 
prognosis. Note: Anti-Ro and anti-La in SLE indicate a good prognosis, due to decreased risk of nephritis and 
vasculitis.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 55-year-old woman presents with dry mouth, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical 
examination finds enlargement of her parotid glands along with marked dryness of her buccal 
mucosa. Laboratory examination finds the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. Which 
of the following statements is not true about this condition?

options.a: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
options.b: Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
options.d: Lacrimal gland is a major target for this disease

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sjogren's syndrome. In this condition, glomerular 
lesions are extremely rare. Defects of tubular function, including renal tubular acidosis, uricosuria, and phosphaturia, are 
often seen and are associated histologically with tubulointerstitial nephritis. Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease, while the respiratory and 
gastrointestinal tracts and the vagina may also be involved. The characteristic decrease in tears 
and saliva (sicca syndrome) is the result of lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and 
salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B 
cells, including plasma cells. Antibodies detected are: • Rheumatoid factor - seen in 75% of patients, whether or not coexisting rheumatoid arthritis is 
present • Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) • SS-A (Ro) - associated with early disease onset, longer disease duration, and extra-glandular 
manifestations, such as cutaneous vasculitis and nephritis • SS-B (La) These patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. About 60% of patients 
have another accompanying autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis, and these 
patients also have the symptoms and signs of that disorder. Biopsy of the lip (to examine minor salivary glands) is essential for the diagnosis of Sjögren's 
syndrome. The image shows an enlargement of the salivary gland with intense lymphocytic and plasma cell 
infiltration with ductal epithelial hyperplasia in the salivary gland. 492 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Mikulicz syndrome is characterized by lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement from any 
cause, including sarcoidosis, lymphomas, and other tumors.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 35-year-old woman presented with complaints of thickening of her skin and the finding 
shown below. On workup, ANA was positive and immunofluorescence showed nucleolar 
pattern. What is the most common extracutaneous manifestation associated with her 485 
Sold by @itachibot condition?
questions.explanation:
The given image is suggestive of microstomia. The findings of skin thickening, microstomia, 
positive ANA, and immunofluorescence showing nucleolar pattern point towards a diagnosis of 
systemic sclerosis. The most common extracutaneous manifestation of systemic sclerosis 
(scleroderma) is Raynaud's phenomenon. Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by episodes of reversible vasoconstriction in the fingers 
and toes on exposure to cold. Rarely, it affects the lips, tip of the nose, and earlobes. These 
episodes classically occur in the following sequence: • Affected part turning pale due to vasoconstriction. • Blue due to ischemia, often associated with numbness or pain. • As blood flow returns, the area turns red with a burning sensation. 493 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 14-year-old girl has the pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis on exposure to 
cold. Which of the following diseases is she likely to develop in the later stages of life?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario suggests that the patient has Raynaud phenomenon, which is 
associated with the risk of developing scleroderma in later stages of life. Raynaud phenomenon is manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of 
the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually 
all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases. The image shows features of Raynaud's phenomenon. Systemic sclerosis is characterized by progressive fibrosis involving the skin, gastrointestinal tract, 
and other tissues. Fibrosis may be the result of the activation of fibroblasts by cytokines produced 
by T cells. 494 
Sold by @itachibot Focal, and sometimes diffuse, subcutaneous calcifications may develop, especially in patients with 
CREST syndrome. The most ominous manifestation is malignant hypertension.

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the most common histological pattern of interstitial lung disease seen in patients 
with systemic sclerosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common histological pattern of interstitial lung disease in systemic sclerosis 
(scleroderma) is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP). It commonly affects the lower lobes 
and is characterised by ground-glass opacities. 495 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is the most common type of ILD in rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following drugs are implicated in systemic sclerosis-like illness?
questions.explanation:
Drugs implicated in systemic sclerosis-like illness are: • Bleomycin • Pentazocine • Cocaine • L-tryptophan-containing dietary supplements Chemicals implicated in systemic sclerosis-like illness are: • Heavy metals • Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) • Toluene • Trichloroethylene Cyclophosphamide and bosentan are used in the treatment of systemic sclerosis (SSc). 
Cyclophosphamide reduces the progression of ILD associated with SSc. Bosentan reduces the risk 
of new ulcers in Raynaud's phenomenon associated with SSc.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 38-year-old woman presents with ulceration over her fingers. She has history of Raynaud's 
phenomenon and GERD since 3 years. Which of the following can be used as a screening test 
for her condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of digital ulcers, Raynaud's phenomenon, and GERD are suggestive of systemic 
sclerosis (scleroderma). Antinuclear antibody (ANA) is the preferred screening test as it is the 
most sensitive test for both limited and diffuse variants of systemic sclerosis. Option B: Anti centromere antibody is the most specific test for CREST syndrome. Option C: Anti topoisomerase I (Scl-70) is the most specific test for diffuse cutaneous systemic 
sclerosis. Option D: Anti-cardiolipin antibody is seen in SLE and APLA syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 47-year-old woman presents with complaints of swollen fingers, heartburn, and occasional 
joint pains. She gives a history suggestive of Raynaud's phenomenon. Physical examination 
reveals taut, thickened skin over her hands and fingers with limited mobility. The presence of 
which of the following antibodies will confirm her diagnosis? 487 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of skin thickening in the hands and fingers (sclerodactyly), Raynaud's 
phenomenon, heartburn (GERD), and occasional arthralgia is suggestive of limited cutaneous 
systemic sclerosis (lcSSc). The presence of anticentromere antibody (ACA) will confirm the 
diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) is positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this 
antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis. 496 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 53-year-old woman presented with thickening of skin over the trunk and proximal parts of 
the limbs. On workup, her serology was found to be positive for anti-topoisomerase I. Which 
of the following features is not likely to be associated with her condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of skin thickening over the trunk and proximal parts of the limbs along with positive 
anti-topoisomerase I antibodies is suggestive of diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc). 
Critical limb ischemia is commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc).

questions.question:
Question 14: Which among the following is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis when 
compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Esophageal dysmotility is more commonly seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) 
compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Systemic sclerosis is divided into two based on the patterns of involvement - diffuse and limited. Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is characteristically associated with CREST syndrome, which 
includes calcinosis cutis, Raynaud’s phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly and 
telangiectasia. Skin involvement, interstitial lung disease (Option C), myopathy (Option B), and scleroderma 
renal crisis (Option D) are more common in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc) than 
limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The incidence of ischemic digital ulcers, CREST features, and primary biliary cirrhosis is more in 
limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The frequency of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is 
equal in both types.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a component of CREST syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Renal failure is not a component of CREST syndrome. CREST syndrome is seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and consists of the 
following: • Calcinosis cutis • Raynaud’s phenomenon • Esophageal dysmotility • Sclerodactyly • Telangiectasia 497 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: An elderly man presents to the ER with severe headache, blurring of vision, and oliguria. 
Examination reveals BP of 200/100mmHg and papilledema. Skin thickening is noted over his 
hands, with contractures in the wrist and fingers. Investigations reveal serum creatinine of 
3mg/dL and peripheral smear shows schistocytes. What is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
498 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scleroderma renal crisis. The drug of choice is ACE 
inhibitors. Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency characterized by acute onset malignant 
hypertension and kidney failure, usually in the absence of previous evidence of significant kidney 
disease. The use of steroids is associated with an increased risk of scleroderma renal crisis. Clinical features of scleroderma renal crisis are: • Accelerated hypertension - headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, hypertensive retinopathy, and 
hypertensive encephalopathy. • Acute kidney injury - oliguria, mild proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, renal failure. • Pulmonary edema, congestive heart failure. • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes), thrombocytopenia. In patients with persistent hypertension, the addition of angiotensin II receptor blockers, calcium 
channel blockers, and direct renin inhibitors should be considered. 499 
Sold by @itachibot Sarcoidosis
